text.p: Following are the top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew apologises unreservedly to the government and people of Malaysia for his criticism of the south Malaysian town of Johor Bru.
- Dhoby Ghaut area looks set to become a bustling hub.
- Britain's House of Commons bans pagers in parliament.
- Singapore Power and Singapore Technologies Telemedia team in joint venture with British Telecom and Japan's NTT Corp to bid for nation's second basic telephone licence.
- Singapore's direct overseas investment hits Singapore $46 billion.
- Corporate raider Johanes Kotjo sells entire 8.4 percent stake in United Pulp & Paper for about Singapore $14.6 million.
- Japanese government cracks down on financial sector crimes.
- Fang Ai Lian, first Singapore woman to head an international accounting firm, is voted Woman of the Year 1996.
- Singapore and Hong Kong markets among hardest hit as regional stocks plunge.
- Gul Technologies' public share offer closes at 135 times subscribed.
- Precision machining company Micro-Machining Industries receives nod for mainboard listing.
- Hotel Properties Ltd beats analysts' forecasts with 51 percent jump in profit to Singapore $44.1 million.
- Electronics contract manufacturer Transtech Electronics targets main-board listing in August to raise Singapore $18 million.
- Close to two-thirds of Hong Kong-based Noble Group Ltd 10.3 million shares to go to small investors.
